Iterative Product Development, Circular Flow Diagram, elements: A circular design with seven numbered elements (1 to 7) representing steps in iterative product development, each accompanied by descriptive text including 'Continuous improvement', 'Collaboration and cross-functional teams', 'Data-driven decision making', 'Rapid prototyping', 'Agile project management', and 'Minimum viable products (MVPs)'.

```mermaid
flowchart LR
  %% Iterative Product Development (circular flow)

  subgraph LOOP[Iterative Product Development]
    direction LR

    n1(("01\nContinuous feedback loops"))
    n2(("02\nMinimum viable products (MVPs)"))
    n3(("03\nAgile project management"))
    n4(("04\nRapid prototyping"))
    n5(("05\nData-driven decision making"))
    n6(("06\nCollaboration and cross-functional teams"))
    n7(("07\nContinuous improvement"))

    n1 --> n2 --> n3 --> n4 --> n5 --> n6 --> n7 --> n1
  end

  classDef step fill:#ffffff,stroke:#666,stroke-width:2px,color:#111;

  class n1,n2,n3,n4,n5,n6,n7 step;
```

ADDIE Model of Instructional Design, Flow Diagram, elements: Five sequential blocks labeled ADDIE (Analysis, Design, Development, Implementation, Evaluation) with brief descriptions below each block, connected by arrows indicating the flow of the process.

Bloom's Taxonomy, Pyramid Diagram, elements: Pyramid structure divided into six layers labeled: Knowledge, Comprehension, Application, Analysis, Synthesis, Evaluation, with increasing complexity from bottom to top.

Bloom's Taxonomy, Pyramid Diagram, elements: Pyramid structure with six layers labeled: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, and Create; a key on the right indicates College and High School levels.

Zone of Proximal Development in Teaching, Graph, elements: Diagonal axis labeled 'Level of Challenge' and 'Level of Competence' with 'Zone of Proximal Development' highlighted. Areas labeled: 'Anxiety' above, 'Boredom' below, indicating learner independence and assistance.

```mermaid flowchart LR %% Axes subgraph Chart["Zone of Proximal Development in Teaching"] direction LR X0((" ")) --- X1["Level of competence →"] Y0((" ")) --- Y1["↑ Level of challenge"] %% Regions Anxiety["Anxiety
(too challenging without support)"] ZPD["Zone of Proximal Development
(with assistance / scaffolding)"] Boredom["Boredom
(too easy / already mastered)"] %% Place regions conceptually Y1 --> Anxiety X1 --> Boredom Anxiety --> ZPD --> Boredom %% Notes N1["What the learner will be able to achieve independently (later)"] N2["What the learner can currently achieve independently"] N3["What the learner can achieve with assistance"] N4["Scaffolding occurs through the support of the more knowing other"] Anxiety -.-> N1 ZPD -.-> N3 Boredom -.-> N2 ZPD -.-> N4 end %% Styling style ZPD fill:#9ad86b,stroke:#2f6b2f,stroke-width:2px style Anxiety fill:#ffffff,stroke:#999,stroke-width:1px style Boredom fill:#ffffff,stroke:#999,stroke-width:1px ```

ADDIE Model, Circular Flow Diagram, elements: Central element labeled 'ADDIE' surrounded by five circles labeled: 'Analysis', 'Design', 'Development', 'Implementation', and 'Evaluation', connected in a circular layout.

```mermaid
flowchart TB
    C((ADDIE))

    A((Analysis))
    D((Design))
    DEV((Development))
    I((Implementation))
    E((Evaluation))

    C --- A
    C --- D
    C --- DEV
    C --- I
    C --- E

    A --> D --> DEV --> I --> E --> A

    classDef center fill:#2f6fb3,stroke:#2f6fb3,color:#fff,font-weight:bold;
    classDef node fill:#2f6fb3,stroke:#2f6fb3,color:#fff;

    class C center;
    class A,D,DEV,I,E node;
```

Porter's Value Chain Analysis, Flow Diagram, elements: Two horizontal sections with 'Supporting activities' and 'Primary activities', each containing labeled boxes for activities, and margins indicated on the right.

```mermaid
flowchart LR
  %% Porter's Value Chain Analysis (layout approximation)

  subgraph VC["Porter's Value Chain Analysis"]
    direction TB

    %% Supporting activities (top block)
    subgraph SA["Supporting activities"]
      direction TB
      FI["Firm infrastructure"]
      HR["Human resource management"]
      TD["Technology development"]
      PR["Procurement"]
      FI --> HR --> TD --> PR
    end

    %% Primary activities (bottom block)
    subgraph PA["Primary activities"]
      direction LR
      IL["Inbound logistics"]
      OP["Production"]
      OL["Outbound logistics"]
      MS["Marketing & sales"]
      SE["Service"]
      IL --> OP --> OL --> MS --> SE
    end

    SA --> PA

    %% Margin (right side)
    M["Margin"]
    SA -.-> M
    PA -.-> M
  end
```

VARK Learning Styles, Circular Diagram, elements: Four quadrants labeled: Visual, Aural, Read/Write, and Kinesthetic, with a central figure representing different learning styles, and teaching tips provided for each style.

```mermaid
flowchart TB

  subgraph VARK["VARK Learning Styles"]
    direction TB

    C((Learning\nStyles))

    subgraph Q1["Visual"]
      direction TB
      VTips["Teaching tips:\n• Use charts/graphs\n• Use images/diagrams\n• Use colors/symbols"]
    end

    subgraph Q2["Aural"]
      direction TB
      ATips["Teaching tips:\n• Lectures/discussion\n• Explain aloud\n• Use stories/examples"]
    end

    subgraph Q3["Read/Write"]
      direction TB
      RTips["Teaching tips:\n• Provide handouts\n• Lists/definitions\n• Encourage note-taking"]
    end

    subgraph Q4["Kinesthetic"]
      direction TB
      KTips["Teaching tips:\n• Hands-on activities\n• Demonstrations\n• Role-play/simulations"]
    end

    %% Connections to center
    C --- Q1
    C --- Q2
    C --- Q3
    C --- Q4

  %% Quadrant styling

  style Q2 fill:#d8f1d2,stroke:#2f7d32,stroke-width:1px

  style Q4 fill:#cfe9ff,stroke:#1f6aa5,stroke-width:1px

  style C fill:#ffffff,stroke:#333333,stroke-width:2px
```

ADDIE Model Timeline, Timeline, elements: A horizontal timeline with labeled years: 1975, Early 80s, Mid 80s, 1995, 1997, and 2000s, each with brief descriptions of developments related to the ADDIE model.

```mermaid
timeline
    title ADDIE Model Timeline
    1975 : FSU creates ADDIE model for U.S. Army (Branson, Rayner, Cox, Furman, King, Hannum, 1975)
    Early 80s : Steps within phases may change to fit an organization's needs (Watson, 1981)
    Mid 80s : ADDIE changes from a waterfall model to a dynamic model (U.S. Army, 1984)
            : The last phase, "Evaluation & Control," is shortened to "Evaluation" (U.S. Army, 1984)
    1995 : ADDIE is first used as an acronym (Schlegel, 1995)
    1997 : Merriënboer (1997) writes that other ID models can be used in conjunction with ADDIE; thus it is a "plug & play" model
    2000s : ADDIE moves beyond a process model (DeSimone, Werner, Harris, 2002) when used to gain direct intuitive insight into a problem
          : While ADDIE strives to identify on-the-job performance (Branson, Rayner, Cox, Furman, Hannum, 1975), it works best with other performance models
```

Solow Growth Model - Effect of Technology, Graph, elements: Graph showing two curves representing capital per worker over time, with annotations for higher technology level effects. Key points labeled: k(0), k*, and k(2). Growth determinants and Solow growth equations noted.

```mermaid
flowchart LR
  %% Solow Growth Model - Change in Technology (A)

  subgraph G["Solow Growth Model - Effect of Technology (A)"]
    direction LR

    subgraph P["Graph: Determinants of Δk/k vs k (capital per worker)"]
      direction TB
      A0["y-axis: Determinants of Δk/k"]:::axis
      X0["x-axis: k = K/L (capital per worker)"]:::axis

      dep["(δ + n)  (break-even investment)"]:::hline

      sA1["sA₁·f(k)/k  (lower technology)"]:::curveLow
      sA2["sA₂·f(k)/k  (higher technology)"]:::curveHigh

      note1["Upper curve has higher technology level than lower curve"]:::note

      k0["k(0)"]:::kp
      k1["k*₁"]:::kp
      k2["k*₂"]:::kp

      k0 --- dep
      k1 --- dep
      k2 --- dep

      k0 -.-> sA1
      k1 -.-> sA1
      k2 -.-> sA2

      sA2 --> note1
    end

    subgraph R["Analysis"]
      direction TB
      ex["Example: Advance in finance theory / computer technology in 1970s (discrete advance)"]:::note
      a1["1. In short run, advance in technology (A) boosts growth rates of capital per worker and GDP per capita."]:::bullet
      a2["2. Growth rates remain higher during transition to steady state."]:::bullet
      a3["3. In long run, growth rates of capital and real GDP per worker fall to zero."]:::bullet
      a4["4. In steady state, higher technology raises steady-state capital per worker (k*₂ > k*₁) and real GDP per capita (y*), not growth rates (remain = 0)."]:::bullet
    end

    subgraph Q["Recall"]
      direction TB
      q1["Production Function:  y = A·f(k)"]:::eq
      q2["Solow Growth Equation:  Δk/k = s·[A·f(k)]/k − δ − n"]:::eq
    end
  end

  classDef axis fill:#ffffff,stroke:#333,stroke-width:1px;
  classDef hline fill:#e6f2ff,stroke:#1f77b4,stroke-width:3px;
  classDef curveLow fill:#ffffff,stroke:#2ca02c,stroke-width:3px;
  classDef curveHigh fill:#ffffff,stroke:#d62728,stroke-width:3px,stroke-dasharray:6 4;
  classDef kp fill:#ffffff,stroke:#666,stroke-width:1px;
  classDef note fill:#fff7cc,stroke:#b59b00,stroke-width:1px;
  classDef bullet fill:#ffffff,stroke:#bbb,stroke-width:1px;
  classDef eq fill:#f7f7ff,stroke:#6666aa,stroke-width:1px;
```

Experiential Learning Cycle, Circular Flow Diagram, elements: Circular layout with four main stages: 'Concrete Experience', 'Reflective Observation', 'Abstract Conceptualisation', and 'Active Experimentation', connected by arrows. Each stage includes descriptive icons and labels.

McKinsey 7-S Framework, Circular Diagram, elements: Central purple circle labeled 'Shared Values' surrounded by six orange and purple circles labeled: 'Strategy', 'Structure', 'Systems', 'Skills', 'Style', and 'Staff'. Arrows indicating connections between elements.

```mermaid flowchart TB %% McKinsey 7-S Framework (circular arrangement) SV((Shared
Values)) STRAT((Strategy)) STRUCT((Structure)) SYS((Systems)) STYLE((Style)) STAFF((Staff)) SKILLS((Skills)) %% Connections to center STRAT <--> SV STRUCT <--> SV SYS <--> SV STYLE <--> SV STAFF <--> SV SKILLS <--> SV %% Outer ring connections STRAT <--> STRUCT STRUCT <--> SYS SYS <--> STYLE STYLE <--> STAFF STAFF <--> SKILLS SKILLS <--> STRAT %% Layout hints STRUCT --- STRAT STRUCT --- SYS STAFF --- SKILLS STAFF --- STYLE %% Styling classDef center fill:#7E57C2,stroke:#6A1B9A,color:#FFFFFF,stroke-width:2px; classDef orange fill:#F39C12,stroke:#D35400,color:#FFFFFF,stroke-width:2px; classDef purple fill:#7E57C2,stroke:#6A1B9A,color:#FFFFFF,stroke-width:2px; class SV center; class STRAT,STRUCT,SYS orange; class SKILLS,STYLE,STAFF purple; ```

Bloom's Taxonomy, Pyramid Diagram, elements: Two pyramids side by side: left shows original Bloom's Taxonomy with layers labeled: Knowledge, Comprehension, Application, Analysis, Synthesis, Evaluation. Right shows Revised Bloom's Taxonomy with layers labeled: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, Create.

Erikson's Stages of Psychosocial Development, Circular Flow Diagram, elements: Circular layout with eight stages labeled: Early Childhood, Preschool, School Age, Adolescence, Young Adulthood, Middle Adulthood, Maturity, and Infancy, each paired with a psychosocial challenge.

```mermaid flowchart LR %% Erikson's Stages of Psychosocial Development — Circular Flow Diagram C([Stages of Psychosocial
Development]) I["Infancy
trust vs. mistrust"] EC["Early Childhood
autonomy vs. shame and doubt"] P["Preschool
initiative vs. guilt"] SA["School Age
industry vs. inferiority"] A["Adolescence
identity vs. role confusion"] YA["Young Adulthood
intimacy vs. isolation"] MA["Middle Adulthood
generativity vs. stagnation"] M["Maturity
ego integrity vs. despair"] I --> EC --> P --> SA --> A --> YA --> MA --> M --> I C --- I C --- EC C --- P C --- SA C --- A C --- YA C --- MA C --- M ```

Shannon Weaver Model of Communication, Network Diagram, elements: Two human figures with speech bubbles. Eight labeled topics distributed around the speech bubbles, including 'First Topic', 'Second Topic', 'Third Topic', 'Fourth Topic', 'Fifth Topic', 'Sixth Topic', and 'Seventh Topic'.

```mermaid
flowchart LR
  %% Shannon Weaver Model of Communication - Network Diagram

  S[Sender] --- B1(( ))
  R[Receiver] --- B2(( ))

  %% Speech bubbles / message cloud (conceptual)
  B1 --- T1((First Topic))
  B1 --- T2((Second Topic))
  B1 --- T3((Third Topic))
  B2 --- T5((Fifth Topic))
  B2 --- T6((Sixth Topic))
  B2 --- T7((Seventh Topic))
  B1 --- T4((Fourth Topic))
  B2 --- T4

  %% Cross-links to resemble a network spread around the bubbles
  T1 --- T2
  T2 --- T3
  T3 --- T6
  T6 --- T7
  T7 --- T5
  T5 --- T4
  T4 --- T3

  classDef person fill:#111,stroke:#111,color:#fff;
  classDef bubble fill:#ffffff,stroke:#999,stroke-width:2px;
  classDef topic fill:#f7f7f7,stroke:#b8b0aa,stroke-width:2px,color:#444;

  class S,R person;
  class B1,B2 bubble;
  class T1,T2,T3,T4,T5,T6,T7 topic;
```

Bloom's Taxonomy Levels, Pyramid Diagram, elements: Pyramid structure with five layers: Remembering (bottom), Understanding, Applying, Analyzing, Evaluating, and Creating (top). Each layer contains associated action verbs.

Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, Pyramid Diagram, elements: Pyramid structure divided into five layers: Physiological, Safety, Love & Belonging, Esteem, and Self-Actualization, with descriptions for each need. Additional labels indicate self-fulfillment and psychological needs.
